Back to list

Transcription for 2005261

This is Duxie, guitarist with the Pieces of Mine.
It's January 1966 in Newport. Work is well underway on the Bringglass tunnels.
The Seven Bridge is nine months away from being opened and we were about to support a London band called The Who
at Coedeva Community College in Cumbrian.
The gig on the 31st of January was yet another of the many promotions of Morris White from the music centre in Skinner Street.
We had already played a few gigs for Moe at Coedeva supporting bands such as the Mojo's and Johnny Kidd and the Pirates.
The Who were originally due to play in a youth centre in Newport, but it was changed probably because Moe White thought the Newport venue to be too small.
The Who concert file by Joe McMichael and Irish Jack Lyons still mistakenly shows the venue as Newport.
It wasn't, as I was there on stage at Coedeva with the Pieces of Mine as a support act.
By 1966 we were down to a four piece of Adrian, Percy, Phil, may he rest in peace, and myself.
I can't remember much of the gig other than we played My Generation just as members of the Who arrived at the side of the stage.
They probably thought we were extremely cheeky to do this, but it was something we did quite often when supporting name groups.
Obviously when they played it our version was made to look quite amateurish, despite a fabulous bass solo from Percy.
When we finished our set and went backstage to the dressing area which was the gym, the Who seemed to be entertaining numerous girls, many of them within the toilets at the end of the room.
Moe White had a load of the My Generation album covers and arranged for the group to sign the backs so he could sell for 10 bob, which was a lot of money, in fact just less than the ticket price of 12 and a tonne.
My girlfriend Jackie, who came with me, managed to get one and that's the only memento I had of the gig, although I recently sold it to a collector.
Adrian and John Beardmore both had posters signed, however John gave his to Will Lowe, so it's somewhere in Australia.
Adrian brought his copy across from Spain in June 2013 and John got it copied, so at least I now have a poster.
Many of those who attended our 50th anniversary reunion gig in 2013 also attended the Who gig in 1966 and I heard lots of stories about it.
Jerry, the 14 year old younger brother of our drummer Phil, was in the gym and managed to speak to all four of the group who he said were very friendly.
Susan Smith and her friends caught a bus from Newport to Cumbrian and once they got into the hall they congregated to the left of the stage and then made a beeline for the centre when the Who came on.
Pete Townsend threw out a guitar string and a plectrum which was supposedly caught by her group, though none of them remember who had them or where they are now.
At one stage during the evening a fag broke out which included a boy they knew from Cumbrian who was a few years older than them.
They missed the bus home and ended up having to walk all the way back to Newport and she was sure they didn't tell their parents that.
For those who don't know the area that must have been six to eight miles depending on where in Newport they lived.
Jeff Cartwright worked in a factory in Cleon called Braids who made garden tools for Spear and Jackson.
It was his first job after leaving school.
At the time of the concert he was friendly with a person who played for a local band and who also worked with him in Braids.
His friend mentioned that if you joined the local weightlifting class there was a good chance of being asked to assist with crowd control.
Jeff weighed about eleven stones soaking wet and because he was a rugby player he joined.
His friend and he were picked and both went to the gig.
The actual evening was a bit of a blur for him as they were positioned right in front of the stage.
He said whilst they had the best view they were supposed to be looking out to the audience.
However his outstanding memories were a Keefe Moon smashing his drums up and throwing them about the stage
and Pete Townsend wrecking his guitar by banging it against the stage floor.
He said the girls in the audience were going mad and he had never experienced anything like it.
Afterwards they were guarding the dressing room and Keefe came out in a fur coat and was quite chatty.
Jeff said for a 17 year old who has been very lucky in life it was certainly one night you will never forget
and was his first and last time as a bouncer.
His children have difficulty believing that the Who would have played in such a small place as Cumbran.
After the Who gig I decided that Andy who had rejoined on bass when Percy left
and I should have speaker cabinets look more impressive than the ones we were using.
I still had a Vox AC30 and I think Andy had a Selma bass amp.
We went to a hardware shop and bought several sheets of 8x4 chipboard
in order to make a couple of cabinets to house Fane speakers we bought from Charlie Marks.
Today Fane speakers seem to have acquired almost a cult status among guitarists
but to be honest in the 60s we bought them because they were cheap not for any supposed tonal qualities.
I read similar stories raving about equipment we used back then.
Watkins dominators were not great amps.
In my opinion they sounded awful but because they had a funny shape and colour
people seemed to think they must have been great.
Modern guitars and amplifiers are far better made than those we had access to.
Would I like to still have the guitars and amplifiers I used in the 60s?
Of course I would but it would be for sentimental or monetary reasons
not for how well they sounded or played.
Anyway back to building cabinets.
Glyn remembers them as being 6 foot tall but I believe they were 8 foot
purely because it would have saved us cutting the chipboard.
The first versions were 8 foot tall, 4 foot wide and 2 foot deep and contained 4 speakers in each cabinet.
They were certainly heavy and a pain to transport as they nearly filled our van.
We tried fitting casters but they kept breaking off so we cut the cabinets in half
probably horizontally however it could have been vertically.
In the end I sort of gave in and agreed that we should go back to more manageable cabinets.
So was this gig special at the time?
To be honest to me it wasn't.
Yes it did influence our playing as a 4 piece particularly with using larger cabinets
but it's only time that it's shown what an achievement it was.
This was hammered home to me when Rod Gilbert mentioned it after a clip of us was used on the Graham Norton show in June 2016.
So thanks Moe, we will always remember you.
you
